claim: If only superheroes who have appeared in live-action films were counted, DC Comics would outnumber Marvel Comics by at least 20.
extra_info: DC refers to publisher_name = 'DC Comics'; Marvel Comics refers to publisher_name = 'Marvel Comics'; difference = SUBTRACT(SUM(publisher_name = 'DC Comics'), SUM(publisher_name = 'Marvel Comics'));
reasoning: The claim requires filtering superheroes based on whether they have appeared in live-action films, but the database contains no tables or columns related to film/movie appearances. This is an out-of-schema concept that cannot be verified from the available data.

content.text: This claim describes a counterfactual/hypothetical scenario: "If only superheroes who have appeared in live-action films were counted..." This requires filtering based on whether superheroes have appeared in live-action films. Let me check whether the database even contains information about film appearances.

input.description: List all tables in the superhero database

content.content:
alignment       colour          hero_attribute  publisher       superhero     
attribute       gender          hero_power      race            superpower

tool_use_result.stdout:
alignment       colour          hero_attribute  publisher       superhero     
attribute       gender          hero_power      race            superpower

input.description: Check schema of superhero and publisher tables

content.content:
CREATE TABLE superhero
(
    id             INTEGER not null
            primary key,
    superhero_name TEXT default NULL,
    full_name      TEXT default NULL,
    gender_id      INTEGER          default NULL,
    eye_colour_id  INTEGER          default NULL,
    hair_colour_id INTEGER          default NULL,
    skin_colour_id INTEGER          default NULL,
    race_id        INTEGER          default NULL,
    publisher_id   INTEGER          default NULL,
    alignment_id   INTEGER          default NULL,
    height_cm      INTEGER          default NULL,
    weight_kg      INTEGER          default NULL,
    foreign key (alignment_id) references alignment(id),
    foreign key (eye_colour_id) references colour(id),
    foreign key (gender_id) references gender(id),
    foreign key (hair_colour_id) references colour(id),
    foreign key (publisher_id) references publisher(id),
    foreign key (race_id) references race(id),
    foreign key (skin_colour_id) references colour(id)
);
CREATE TABLE publisher
(
    id             INTEGER not null
            primary key,
    publisher_name TEXT default NULL
);

tool_use_result.stdout:
CREATE TABLE superhero
(
    id             INTEGER not null
            primary key,
    superhero_name TEXT default NULL,
    full_name      TEXT default NULL,
    gender_id      INTEGER          default NULL,
    eye_colour_id  INTEGER          default NULL,
    hair_colour_id INTEGER          default NULL,
    skin_colour_id INTEGER          default NULL,
    race_id        INTEGER          default NULL,
    publisher_id   INTEGER          default NULL,
    alignment_id   INTEGER          default NULL,
    height_cm      INTEGER          default NULL,
    weight_kg      INTEGER          default NULL,
    foreign key (alignment_id) references alignment(id),
    foreign key (eye_colour_id) references colour(id),
    foreign key (gender_id) references gender(id),
    foreign key (hair_colour_id) references colour(id),
    foreign key (publisher_id) references publisher(id),
    foreign key (race_id) references race(id),
    foreign key (skin_colour_id) references colour(id)
);
CREATE TABLE publisher
(
    id             INTEGER not null
            primary key,
    publisher_name TEXT default NULL
);

content.text:
The database has no information about film appearances (live-action or otherwise). There are no tables or columns related to movies, films, or media appearances. The claim asks us to filter superheroes based on whether they've appeared in live-action films, which is a concept entirely outside the database schema.

This is an **OUT-OF-SCHEMA** claim — the database contains no data about live-action film appearances, making it impossible to verify or refute the claim.
